linkTarget.anchoringText: Firstly, production rates of some MFHWs are still low after fracturing treatments and the oil production rates for wells #A1 and #A2 are even lower than 1.5 m3/d, shown in Figure 1a. Secondly, production rates decline quickly for some other wells (e.g. wells #A3 and #A4) as shown in Figure 1b. Thirdly, the water-cut may rise to 90% only after two or three yearsâ€™ water flooding development (e.g. wells #A5 and #A6), shown in Figure 1c, and the water-cut of other MFHWs rapidly increases to 100% (e.g. wells #A7 and #A8) as shown in Figure 1d. Many wells have been shut-in due to high water-cut.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Production rates and water-cut curves of MFHWs in Changqing oil field: (a) well #A1; (b) well #A2; (c) well #A3; (d) well #A4; (e) well #A5; (f) well #A6; (g) well #A7; (h) well #A8.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production rates and water-cut curves of MFHWs in Changqing oil field: (a) well #A1; (b) well #A2; (c) well #A3; (d) well #A4; (e) well #A5; (f) well #A6; (g) well #A7; (h) well #A8.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Therefore, it has proven to be challenging because of complex and dynamic behaviors of reservoir and well during production. For instance, formation damage (i.e. fracturing fluid retention) and fracture closure (i.e. proppant broken) will increase the flow resistance both from matrix to fractures and fractures to wellbore in different degrees along horizontal wellbore, and water breakthrough can lead to high watercut rapidly, shown in Figure 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Schematic of an MFHW in a tight oil reservoir with oil-saturation heterogeneity, formation damage (fracturing fluid retention), fracture closure (broken proppant), and water breakthrough.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic of an MFHW in a tight oil reservoir with oil-saturation heterogeneity, formation damage (fracturing fluid retention), fracture closure (broken proppant), and water breakthrough.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Some PLT results also demonstrate this phenomenon in the Ordos tight oil reservoir as shown in Figure 3. We can also find that hydraulic fractures are not uniformly distributed along horizontal wellbore, and the production distribution is nonuniform for these two MFHWs. Some fractures made little contribution to production rates or all fluids from some fractures are water so that the water-cut of the first well is close to 100%. Therefore, we should address this problem to estimate production contribution of individual fracture and diagnose the water-breakthrough sections to improve well performance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: PLT results of two MFHWs in a tight oil reservoir in China.

formatted-caption.caption-text: PLT results of two MFHWs in a tight oil reservoir in China.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The main objective of using ERT in this paper is to provide a reliable temporal description of the waterflood front propagation around MFHWs resulting from the water flooding. It can reduce the nonuniqueness of well testing interpretation too. Then, the water-breakthrough segments of MFHWs can be estimated by ERT results. We combine the well testing method with ERT to assess production contribution of fractures and water-breakthrough locations for well performance evaluation, and further compare the results with PLT data, as show in Figure 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Schematic of the method proposed in this paper.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic of the method proposed in this paper.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Physical and Mathematical model. To solve the problem in Figure 2, the physical model of an MFHW was developed, shown in Figure. 5. Some assumptions are made to get the solutions.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Physical model of an MFHW intercepted by asymmetric fractures with arbitrary locations, unequal production and conductivity in the horizontal-slab reservoir.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Physical model of an MFHW intercepted by asymmetric fractures with arbitrary locations, unequal production and conductivity in the horizontal-slab reservoir.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Li et al. (1996) considered the pressure drop caused by linear flow with uniform flux density along the fracture. Whereas, the flux density along individual fracture is nonuniform since fluids may flow into the fracture from different directions and positions, and fluids will then converge to the horizontal wellbore. He et al. (2016a) considered both nonuniform-flux-density linear flow and radial flow within fractures. We extend this method to deal with asymmetric fractures, in which radial flow and nonuniform-flux-density linear flow are incorporated, seen in Figure 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Diagram of nonuniform-flux-density linear flow and radial flow within a fracture.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diagram of nonuniform-flux-density linear flow and radial flow within a fracture.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Unstructured perpendicular bisector (PEBI) grid system is applied in the numerical model, shown in Figure 7a. The calculation results between numerical model in Saphir and analytical model in this paper are shown in Figure 7b. It presents a good agreement between them except for the later period of linear flow, which is perhaps caused by the difference of fracture characterization in numerical and analytical well-testing models.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: (a) PEBI grid system in the numerical model; (b) comparison of calculation results between numerical well testing model in Saphir and analytical model in this paper.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) PEBI grid system in the numerical model; (b) comparison of calculation results between numerical well testing model in Saphir and analytical model in this paper.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: PEBI grid system in the numerical model
comparison of calculation results between numerical well testing model in Saphir and analytical model in this paper

linkTarget.anchoringText: To analyze pressure-transient behavior and flow regimes of an MFHW, we develop the type curve of an MFHW intercepted by multiple nonuniformly distributed and asymmetric fractures with different conductivity and production contribution, as shown in Figure 8. The input parameters are shown in Table 2 and Figure 8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: The type curve of an MFHW intercepted by multiple nonuniformly distributed and asymmetric fractures with different production contribution and fracture conductivity.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The type curve of an MFHW intercepted by multiple nonuniformly distributed and asymmetric fractures with different production contribution and fracture conductivity.

linkTarget.anchoringText: We choose seven cases to characterize the production contribution of fractures as shown in Figure 9a and Figure 9b. Seven examples are divided into two groups, and type curves are obtained respectively, shown in Figure 9c and Figure 9d. The effects of production distribution are mainly reflected in four regimes (i.e. transitional flow, linear flow, early-radial flow, and biradial flow). The duration of early-radial-flow regime depends on the interference among fractures.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: (a) and (b) seven kinds of production contribution of individual fracture; (c) type curves under the situation in (a); (d) type curves under the situation in (b).

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) and (b) seven kinds of production contribution of individual fracture; (c) type curves under the situation in (a); (d) type curves under the situation in (b).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: seven kinds of production contribution of individual fracture
seven kinds of production contribution of individual fracture
type curves under the situation in (a)
type curves under the situation in (b)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Hydraulic fractures may be nonuniformly distributed along wellbore for field cases since it depends on the stress, properties of rocks, etc. Thus, five cases are selected to describe typical situations of fracture distribution. The type curves are shown in Figure 10. This factor influences linear flow, early-radial flow, and biradial flow. It is also observed that early-radial flow regime disappears due to strong interference among fractures (e.g. xwiD: 0.10-0.15-0.20-0.25-0.30). When fracture spacing become larger (e.g. xwiD: 0.10-0.45-0.50-0.55-0.90, xwiD: 0.10-0.75-0.80-0.85-0.90), early-radial flow gradually become obvious and two horizontal lines can be observed. In conclusion, the period of early-radial flow is dominated by the interference among fractures.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Type curves of an MFHW intercepted by nonuniformly distributed fractures.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Type curves of an MFHW intercepted by nonuniformly distributed fractures.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Different fracturing scale and fracture closure may result in unequal conductivity of fractures. We analyze influences of fracture conductivity on pressure response under two conditions. Total fracture conductivity and other parameters keep the same. The wellbore is assumed to be uniformly intercepted by five symmetric factures with equal production and conductivity in the first case. There exist differences between equal and unequal conductivity of fractures as shown in Figure 11a.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Type curves of an MFHW with arbitrary conductivity of individual fracture with: (a) equal and (b) unequal spacing, production, conductivity, and fracture half-length.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Type curves of an MFHW with arbitrary conductivity of individual fracture with: (a) equal and (b) unequal spacing, production, conductivity, and fracture half-length.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: unequal spacing, production, conductivity, and fracture half-length

linkTarget.anchoringText: Furthermore, we compare transient-pressure behaviors under different total fracture conductivity, shown in Figure 12. It is observed that fracture conductivity is one of the most significant parameters that affect the production performance of MFHWs. The effects of fracture conductivity on pressure behaviors can be ignored when CfD is higher than 50.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Type curves of an MFHW with different total fracture conductivity.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Type curves of an MFHW with different total fracture conductivity.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Obviously, the length of individual fracture is different from each other. Similarly, each fracture is asymmetric in fact. We design seven examples to investigate the influences of asymmetric fractures on type curves, shown in Figure 13. In the first four cases, the ratio of fractures with the half-length of 20m and 100m account for fifty percent respectively. It is shown that four curves coincide when we change the arrangements of different half-length as shown in Figure 13a.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Type curves of an MFHW with unequal fracture half-length of two wings.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Type curves of an MFHW with unequal fracture half-length of two wings.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Firstly, some parameters can be obtained (e.g., well length, formation thickness, perforation locations), but some others are uncertain (e.g., fracture half-length, permeability, flux of individual fracture). Secondly, we define range to better constrain parameters (e.g., half-length varying from 0 to 200 m, production contribution of fractures changing between 0 and 1). Finally, we should check whether the interpretation results accord with the well-known results (e.g., average permeability). The history matching results are shown in Figure 14.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: History matching results of well #A using the well testing model in this paper.

formatted-caption.caption-text: History matching results of well #A using the well testing model in this paper.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The distribution of electrical resistivity and waterflood front for #A are shown in Figure 15a and Figure 15b. The waterflood fronts have already arrived at #A, and the water-breakthrough positions mainly locate at the first, second, ninth, and tenth perforations followed by the third perforations, shown in Figure 15b. Considering the combination of fractures in well testing interpretation, the water-breakthrough positions from ERT correspond to the first and fifth segments for well testing results.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: ERT results of #A: (a) electrical resistivity distribution; (b) waterflood front distribution.

formatted-caption.caption-text: ERT results of #A: (a) electrical resistivity distribution; (b) waterflood front distribution.

linkTarget.anchoringText: PLT was conducted to measure downhole flow profile. Results are shown in Figure 16. The phenomenon of nonuniform production is obvious, and well #B only produces water. Specific information can be found in Table 5. It is worth noting that the last four perforations were combined together to obtain a total rate during the process PLT test.

Well #B is an MFHW, belonging to the Chang 7 tight oil reservoir in the Ordos Basin, China. It has been put into production since 2013. The water-cut vary from 50% to 70%, shown in Figure 17. Pressure test and ERT test were carried out in 2016 to evaluate production performance and detect water-breakthrough locations along horizontal wellbore to avoid rapid rise of water-cut and decrease of oil production rates.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Production rates and water-cut curves of well #B.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production rates and water-cut curves of well #B.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Similarly, we combine nine fractures into four groups to reduce the multiplicity. With reference to the interpretation of well #A, the history matching curves are shown in Figure 18. Feld test data match well with the well testing model in this paper except for transitional flow regime and the late period of linearflow regime. Interpretation results of #B and reservoir properties are shown in Table 8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: History matching results of well #B by use of the well testing model in this paper.

formatted-caption.caption-text: History matching results of well #B by use of the well testing model in this paper.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The distribution of electrical resistivity and waterflood front of well #B are shown in Figure 19a and Figure 19b. The waterflood fronts have just arrived at well #B, and the water-breakthrough positions locate at the fourth and fifth perforations, shown in Figure 19b.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: ERT results of #B: (a) electrical resistivity distribution; (b) waterflood front distribution.

formatted-caption.caption-text: ERT results of #B: (a) electrical resistivity distribution; (b) waterflood front distribution.
